Award.AbstractNarration: Oxygen is needed for the production of sufficient cellular energy to sustain life. Low oxygen availability, or anoxia, therefore has devastating effects on the viability of many organisms, including plants. Reduction in oxygen levels can come from the plant's own consumption of the available oxygen in densely packed tissues, or from the vagaries of the surroundings such as soil compaction, seasonal flooding and even agricultural practices related to cultivation or irrigation. Surviving these conditions requires the plant to sense the lowering of oxygen availability and shift its energy metabolism to systems to cope with the impending energy deficit. Although this response is essential for survival, our current understanding of this sensory system in plants is highly incomplete, especially at the level of the cellular events that sense and signal a fall in oxygen availability. Therefore, the research in this proposal seeks to more fully characterize the early events that trigger, coordinate and regulate plant responses to low oxygen availability using an integrated approach of imaging of low oxygen-related cellular signaling activities, characterization of associated changes in gene expression and analysis of the responses of mutants impaired in these cell and molecular events. In addition to advancing fundamental knowledge of how plants adapt to the environment, the research in this proposal will also be of long-term relevance to agriculture where seasonal flooding, likely exacerbated by climate change, may become a significant factor in future crop productivity. Integrated into this basic research is also an effort to develop a plant biology movie resource aimed at engaging and educating the general public. This effort will intimately involve undergraduate students in the making and presentation of the movies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants naturally experience low oxygen environments when, for example, fields become flooded and water fills the air pockets found in the soil. Similarly, blooms of soil microbes can consume available oxygen and even dense tissues within the plant can block free entry of oxygen, allowing regions of low oxygen to form inside the plant body. Plant roots need oxygen to generate energy and so these low oxygen environments cause stress and possibly even death of the plant by causing cellular energy to drop to dangerously low levels. However, plants have developed the ability to cope with short-term low oxygen stress by shifting their metabolism to an oxygen-independent energy forming system and by altering development to generate structures more able to channel available oxygen throughout the plant body. In order to trigger these responses, plants must be able to sense and then signal their oxygen availability. This signaling system operates at the cellular level and research performed under this grant has dissected the role for cellular calcium changes in this response. Thus, alterations in cellular calcium provide one important element that can trigger the switching on of genes that aid the plant in adapting to low oxygen levels. Calcium moves in and out of the cell using pumps and channels and two of these transporters called ACA1 and CAX2 appear critical for limiting the size of the calcium signal generated as oxygen levels fall. Mutants that disrupt the genes for these transporters generate larger calcium signals as oxygen levels lower, switch on genes associated with low oxygen tolerance and are more resistant to damage by low oxygen levels. In addition, there is much natural variation in low oxygen tolerance amongst plants and this research also shows that this variation can likewise be linked to calcium signaling. More resistant variants within the plant Arabidopsis (Mouse ear cress) show larger calcium signals and more rapid recovery from low oxygen stress. One further element revealed by this research is that calcium changes can propagate throughout the plant as a rapidly moving wave of increased calcium. This wave system appears important for allowing distant parts within the plant to monitor the activities of the rest of the plant body. In addition to advancing basic knowledge about sensory systems, this research is defining molecular signaling elements within the plant that present opportunities for targeted breeding or the engineering of plants more able to withstand agronomically important stresses such as seasonal flooding.

A local outreach program has been developed associated with this research program with a hands-on microscopy 'exploration station' that showcases plant cell biology and discusses plant signaling to stressful environments such as low oxygen. This outreach effort has been presented at 3-4 events per year over the last 4 years, with a mix of K-12 audiences and events aimed at a more general public. This research has also provided opportunities for outreach to a wider audience through providing movies of plant signaling responses and explanatory animations built around core concepts of plant physiology and development.
